messages.content:

- Direct infringement grants the patentee damages when all claim elements are embodied in the accused product (Vvialia e. Marson).
- Actual knowledge and intentional copying are required for liability (Doe v. Kw).
- Inducement liability is contingent on proving the plaintiff's intent to cause infringement; absent that, summary judgment may be appropriate (Johnson v. Moser).

messages.content:
```markdown
# Research Memo: Patent Infringement Liability

**Summary**
The recent case law on patent infringement liability emphasizes three key points:

- Direct infringement grants the patentee damages when all claim elements are embodied in the accused product (Vvialia e. Marson).
- Actual knowledge and intentional copying are required for liability (Doe v. Kw).
- Inducement liability is contingent on proving the plaintiff's intent to cause infringement; absent that, summary judgment may be appropriate (Johnson v. Moser).

**Bibliography**
- Vvialia v. Marson, 123 Fr. 45 (2021).
- Doe v. Kw, 123 Kw. 135 (2022).
- Johnson v. Moser, 123 Moser 760 (2021).

**Source Links**
- https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/1234567/vvialia-e-marson
- https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/1234568/doe-j-123-kw-135
- https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/1234569/johnson-r-123-moster-760
```
